node.title: When it comes to self-defense, the burden is often on the prosecution.
node.alt: Jurors appeared to be swayed by Kyle Rittenhouseâ€™s claim that he had acted in self-defense when he shot three men, killing two.
node.description: The acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse points to the wide berth given to defendants who say they acted out of fear.
node.content: ["For many Americans, the acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse on all charges on Friday was a vindication of an innocent, if not heroic, teenager with good intentions. For others, it was a brutal disappointment, further evidence that the courts give white men a pass for their actions.", "But for legal scholars, it was not a surprise. Once Mr. Rittenhouse claimed that he had acted in self-defense when he shot three men, killing two, during unrest following the police shooting of a Black man in Kenosha, Wis., the onus was on the prosecution to prove otherwise.", "\u201cWhen people look at this, and they\u2019re feeling frustrated, they\u2019re not recognizing just how high the prosecutors\u2019 burden is here,\u201d said Cecelia Klingele, a University of Wisconsin law professor. \u201cIt was a real uphill battle to get out from under self-defense.\u201d", "The acquittal points to the wide berth the legal system gives to defendants who say they acted out of fear, even if others around them were also afraid.", "Wisconsin\u2019s rules for self-defense are well within the national mainstream. If people reasonably believe they are at risk of death or great bodily harm, they can use deadly force. Most states say that someone who provokes violence or is acting illegally waives the right to self-defense, but Wisconsin allows it if the person has \u201cexhausted every other reasonable means to escape from or otherwise avoid death or great bodily harm.\u201d", "The state does not have a full-fledged \u201cstand your ground\u201d statute that exists in at least 30 states, but people who believe they are threatened do not have a duty to retreat if they can.", "Such rules can be combustible when juxtaposed against the state\u2019s open carry law, which allows for situations like the one at issue in the trial, where numerous strangers were armed and had taken it upon themselves to maintain order.", "Self-defense laws typically do not require someone to have good judgment and tend to consider only the moments leading up to the violence, not whether the person willingly entered a turbulent situation or contributed to the chaos.", "\u201cDo you look at the choice to go to a heated, confrontational area with a weapon that would be scary to a lot of people?\u201d said Samuel Buell, a former federal prosecutor who teaches at Duke University School of Law, speaking of Mr. Rittenhouse. \u201cYou can\u2019t really say that he doesn\u2019t have a right to do that because of the status of gun laws.\u201d", "Similarly, even though the three men on trial for the killing of Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia chased him through a suburban neighborhood, they are claiming self-defense because, they say, Mr. Arbery tried to get control of a shotgun one was carrying.", "Gun laws have generally become more permissive \u2014 open carry is now legal, to one degree or another, in almost every state. Gun purchases have soared and the Supreme Court appears poised to gut New York State\u2019s handgun permit requirement in a Second Amendment case.", "\u201cIf we\u2019re going to have a country in which guns are pervasive and the law has little or nothing to say about where and when one may carry a gun and display a gun,\u201d Mr. Buell said, \u201cthen we are going to have a situation where self-defense law can\u2019t really handle it.\u201d", "The reasonable fear standard for self-defense has given rise to concerns that it is affected by the same racial bias that permeates the justice system. A mountain of social science research shows that Black people, men in particular, are more likely to be seen as threatening.", "\u201cThe message that this case sends is to shoot first, ask questions later,\u201d said Kami Chavis, director of the criminal justice program at Wake Forest Law. She added, \u201cIf we change the race, the age, the victims, if we change some of these dynamics we very well could have had a different result.\u201d", "Mr. Rittenhouse went to downtown Kenosha with a military-style assault rifle slung to his chest, saying he wanted to protect property and volunteer as a medic, though he was only 17 years old and not a certified E.M.T.", "During the unrest he was pursued by a man, Joseph Rosenbaum, who Mr. Rittenhouse said he feared would wrest control of his gun. Mr. Rittenhouse shot and killed him. That, according to evidence presented at the trial, caused members of the crowd to perceive Mr. Rittenhouse as a dangerous aggressor.", "One man, Anthony Huber, used a skateboard as a weapon against him. Mr. Rittenhouse shot and killed him before facing off with a third man, Gaige Grosskreutz, who had pulled out a handgun. Mr. Rittenhouse wounded him in the arm.", "Even assuming that everyone involved had the best of intentions, it would be difficult to tell aggressors from defenders. A police officer testified that so many armed people were roving the area that when Mr. Rittenhouse approached with his hands up, he made no connection to the shootings that had occurred. ", "The jury was not asked to consider whether Mr. Rittenhouse was in error for bringing a gun to a volatile situation. The only gun charge against Mr. Rittenhouse \u2014 possession of a dangerous weapon by a person under 18 \u2014 was dismissed at the 11th hour. The judge agreed with a defense argument that the law made an exception for long guns, a common provision that allows teenagers to hunt. The law was written at a time when military-style assault rifles were not widely available.", "Since the Parkland, Fla., school shooting in 2018, in which the gunman was 19, Florida, California and Vermont have raised the age to purchase a long gun to 21, and Washington State did the same for semiautomatic rifles.", "A Gallup poll last year showed that support for gun regulation, which surged after the Parkland shooting, has ebbed during the coronavirus pandemic and a spike in violent crime. Still, a healthy majority of Americans support stricter gun laws.", "\u201cWhat happened in Kenosha isn\u2019t some fluke,\u201d said Nick Suplina, senior vice president for Law & Policy at Everytown for Gun Safety. \u201cIt\u2019s the logical consequence of state and federal laws being written by the N.R.A. and going unopposed for decades.\u201d", "For many who followed the case, especially on the political left, the verdict raised uncomfortable questions about the scope of self-defense laws. Mayor Satya Rhodes-Conway of Madison, Wis., called the verdict \u201cdeeply disturbing\u201d and expressed concern about the message it sent.", "\u201cUnfortunately, this will perpetuate distrust in the justice system and further normalize gun violence,\u201d Ms. Rhodes-Conway said in a statement. \u201cAllowing vigilantism to masquerade as self-defense is a terrible precedent.\u201d", "Janine Geske, a former Wisconsin Supreme Court justice who now teaches at Marquette University Law School, said the trial was an instance in which many people\u2019s opinions about what was morally acceptable clashed with the jury\u2019s interpretation of what the law allowed.", "\u201cI, too, share that view that had he not brought that gun into Kenosha that day, and just come with his medic bag, we probably would not have had any deaths,\u201d Ms. Geske said.", "Ms. Geske said she believed that the jurors could have defensibly reached a guilty verdict. They could have, for example, decided that Mr. Rittenhouse's fear of death or great bodily harm was not reasonable in the situation.", "\u201cIt\u2019s hard, because most of the victims at some point were approaching Rittenhouse,\u201d Ms. Geske said. \u201cAll those factors made it hard for the jury to be satisfied that it wasn\u2019t a reasonable belief.\u201d"]
